qas.question: When was Science of Logic written?
Who was the author of Science of Logic?
Why did Hegel believe natural things are less real than spiritual things?
Along with God and morally responsible people, what is an example of a spiritual thing to Hegel?
What is an example of a school of thought Hegel believed to be wrong?

plausible_answers.text: they depend on other finite qualities

qas.question: Why did Hegel argue that finite qualities were real?

plausible_answers.text: morally responsible people, ethical communities and God

qas.question: What are examples of natural things?

context: In his Science of Logic (<a0_0><b6_0>1812<b6_0/>–<b7_0>1814<b7_0/><a0_0/>) <a1_0>Hegel<a1_0/> argues that finite qualities are not fully "real" because <b5_0>they depend on other finite qualities<b5_0/> to determine them. Qualitative infinity, on the other hand, would be more self-determining and hence more fully real. Similarly finite natural things are less "real"—because they are <a2_0>less self-determining<a2_0/>—than spiritual things like <b9_0>morally responsible people, <a3_0>ethical communities<a3_0/> and God<b9_0/>. So any doctrine, such as <a4_0><b8_0>materialism<b8_0/><a4_0/>, that asserts that finite qualities or natural objects are fully real is mistaken.
